sp.p: Well, for this day I will stay at home, and for the future|time I will consider.

div.head: Scene 20.
div.stage: Enter two Servants of the Generals.

sp.speaker: I. Servant.
sp.p: This boy that came but the other day, hath got more of my Lords affection, than we that have served him this many years.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant.
sp.p: New-comers are alwaies more favoured than old waiters; for Masters regards old Servants no more, than the Imagerie in an old suit of Hang|ing, which are grown threed-bare with time, and out of fashion with change; Besides, new Servants are more industrious and diligent than old; but when he hath been here a little while, he will be as lazie as the rest, and then he will be as we are.

sp.speaker: I. Servant.
sp.p: I perceive my Lord delights to hear him talk, for he will listen very a tentively to him, but when we offer to speak, he bids us to be silent.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant.
sp.p: I wonder he should, for when we speak, it is with gravity, and our discourse is sententious, but his is meer squibs.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Lord would have one of you to come to him.

sp.speaker: I. Servant.
sp.p: Why, I thought you could supply all our places, for when you are with him, he seems to have no use of us.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: It shall not be for want of will, but ability, if I do not serve him in every honest office.

sp.speaker: I. Servant.
sp.p: So you will make some of us knaves.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I cannot make you knaves, unless you be willing to be knaves your selves.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant.
sp.p: What, do you call me knave?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I do not call you so.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant.
sp.p: Well, I will be revenged, if I live.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfull, and Reformer her woman.

sp.speaker: REformer.
sp.p: Madam, I have inquired what this Sir Serious Dumb is, and 'tis said he is one of the finest Gentlemen in this Kingdom, and that his va|lour hath been proved in the wars, and that he is one that is very active and dexterous in all manly exercises, as riding, fencing, vaulting, swimming, and the like, Also that he is full of inventions, and a rare Poet, and that he hath a great Estate, only that he is dumb, and hath been so this twelve years and up|wards.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Reformer. What makes you so industrious to inquire after him, surely thou art in love within.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: In my conscience I liked him very well, when he was to see you.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: The truth is, he cannot weary you with words, nor anger you in his discourse, but pray do not inquire after him, nor speak of him; for people will think I have some designe of marriage.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: I shall obey you, Madam.

div.head: Scene. 22.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Singularity, and Affectionata.

sp.speaker: LOrd Singularity.
sp.p: Affectionata, Thou art one of the diligent'st boys that had.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: How can I be otherwise, Sir, since you are the Governour of my soul, that commands the Fort of my passion, and the Castle of my ima|ginations, which are the heart, and the head.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Do you love me so much?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: So well my Lord, as you are the archetectour of my mind, the foundation of my thoughts, and the gates of my memories, for your will is the form, your happiness the level, and your actions the treasurie.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Thy wit delights me more, than thy flattery perswades: for I cannot believe a boy can love so much; Besides, you have not served me so long, as to beget love.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I have loved you from my infancy, for as I suck'd life from my Nurses breast, so did I Love from fames, drawing your praises forth, as I did milk, which nourished my affections.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: I shall strive; boy, to require thy love.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: To requite, is to return love for love.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: By Heaven? I love thee, as a Father loves a son.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Then I am blest,

sp.speaker: 1. SOuldier.
sp.p: What is this boy that our General is so taken with.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier,
sp.p: A poor Begger-boy!

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Can a poor Begger-boy merit his affections?

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: He is a pretty boy, and waites very diligently.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: So doth other boys, as well as he, but I believe he is a young Pimp, and carries, and conveys Love-letters.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Like enough to, for boys are strangely crafty in those imployments, and so industrious, as they will let no times nor opportunities slip them, but they will find waies to deliver their Letters and messages.

div.head: Scene 24.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfulls Page, and Sir Serious Dumb, who gives a Note to the Page to read.

sp.speaker: PAge.
sp.p: Sir, I dare not direct you to my Lady, as you desire me in this Note, and if I should tell her, here is a Gentleman that desired to visit her, she would refuse your visit.

div.stage: Dumb gives the young Page four or five pieces of Gold.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I will direct you to the room wherein my Lady is, but I must not be seen, nor confess I shewed you the way.

div.stage: Page, and Sir Serious Dumb Exeunt

div.head: Scene 25.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Singularity, and Affectionata.

sp.speaker: LOrd Singularity.
sp.p: Come Affectionata, sit down and entertain me with thy sweet discourse, which makes all other company troublesome, and tedi|ous to me, thine only doth delight me.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: My Noble Lord? I wish the plat-form of my brain were a Garden of wit, and then perchance my tongue might present your Excellen|cies with a Posie of flowery Rhethorick, but my poor brain is barren, wanting

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Thou hast an eloquent tongue, (and a gentle soul.)

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: My Noble Lord, I have hardly learn'd my native words, much less the eloquence of Language, and as for the souls of all mankind, they are like Common-wealths, where the several vertues, and good graces are the Citizens therein, and the natural subjects thereof; but vices and follies, as the thievish Borderers, and Neighbour-enemies, which makes inrodes, factions, mutinies, intrudes and usurps Authority, and if the follies be more than the good graces, and the vices too strong for the vertues, the Monarchy of a good life falls to ruine, also it is indangered by Civil-wars amongst the pas|sions.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: What passions indangers it most?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Anger, malice, and despair.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Were you never angry?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I am of too melancholly a nature, to be very angry.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Why? are melancholly persons never angry?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Very seldom, my Lord, for those that are naturally melanchol|ly, doth rather grieve, than fret, they sooner wast into sighes, than fly about with fury; more tears flows thorough their eyes, than words pass thorough their lips.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Why should you be melancholly?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Alas, nature hath made me so; Besides, I find there is not much reason to joy, for what we love, perchance it loves not us, and if it doth, we cannot keep it long, for pleasures passeth like a dream; when pains doth stay, as if eternal were.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Thou art composed with such harmonie, as thy discourse is as delightfull musick, wherein the soul takes pleasure.

div.head: Scene 26.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfull, Sir Serious Dumb following her, where Reformer her Woman meets them.

sp.speaker: REformer.
sp.p: Madam, now the Gentleman is here, you must use him civilly, and not strive to run away from him, wherefore pray turn, and entertain him.

div.stage: The Lady Bashfull turns to him, but is so out of countenance, and trembles so much, as she cannot speak, but stands still and mute; All the while he fixes his eyes upon her.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Pray speak to him, Madam, and not stand trembling, as if you were like to fall.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: My spirits is seized on by my bashfull and innocent fears, in|somuch, as they have not strength to support my body without trem|bling.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Sweet Madam, try not speak to him?

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p:
Honourable Sir? give me leave to tell you, that my bash|fullness
doth smother the senses and reason in my brain, and chokes the words in my throat I should utter, but pray do not think it proceeds from crimes, but an imperfection of nature, which I have strove against, but cannot as yet rectifie
sp.stage: Sir Serious Dumb Civily bows to her, and then gives Reformer his Table-book to read.

p.hi: He hath writ here, that had his tongue liberty to speak, all that he could say, would be so far below, and inferiour to what might be said in your praise, as he should not adventure to presume to speak.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: I will presume to break my brain, but I will invent some ways to be rid of his company.

div.head: Scene 27.
div.stage: Enter the General, and sits in a melancholly posture. Enters Affectionata, and stands with a sad countenance.

sp.speaker: LOrd Singularity.
sp.p: What makes thee look so sad, my boy?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: To see you sit so melancholly.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Clear up thy countenance, for its not a deadly melancholly, though it is a troublesome one.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: May I be so bold to ask the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: The cause is, a cruel Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Have you a Mistriss, and can she be cruel?

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: O! Women are Tyrants, they daw us on to love, and then denies our suits.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Will not you think me rude, If I should question you?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: No, for thy questions delights me more, than my Mistriss de|nials grieves me.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Then give me leave to ask you, whether your suit be just?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Just, to a Lovers desires.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: What is your desire?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: To lye with her.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: After you have married her?

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Marry her saist thou, I had rather be banish'd from that Sex for ever, than marry one, and yet I love them well.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Why have you such an adversion to marriage, being lawfull and honest.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Because I am affraid to be a Cuckold!

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Do you think there is no chaste women?

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Faith boy, I believe very few, and those that are men, knows not where to find them out, for all that are not married, professes cha|stity, speaks soberly, and looks modestly, but when they are martyed, they are more wild than Bachalins, far worse than Satyres, making their Husbands horns far greater than a Stags, having more branches sprouts thereon.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: And doth he never cast those horns?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Yes, if he be a Widower, he casts his horns, only the marks remains, otherwise he bears them to his grave.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: But put the case you did know a woman that was chaste; would not you marry her?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: That is a question not to be resolved, for no man can be resol|ved, whether a womam can be chaste or not.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Why do you sighe, my boy?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Because all women are false, or thought to be so, that wise men dares not trust them.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: But they are fools, that will not try, and make use of them, if they can have them; wherefore I will go, and try my Mistriss once again.

div.head: Scene. 28.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Ignorance, and her Maid.

sp.speaker: LAdy Ignorance.
sp.p: What a noise they make below, they will disturb my Husbands study; go and tell those of my Servants, that I will turn them away for their carelesness, as that they cannot place, set, or hold things sure, but let them fall to maké such a noise.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I shall.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: It shall be my study how to order my house without noise, wherefore all my Servants shall be dumb, although not deaf, and I will take none, but such as have corns on their feet, that they may tread gently, and all my Houshold-vessel shall be of wood, for wood makes not such a noise when it chance to fall, or is hit against a wall, as metal doth, which rings like bells, when it is but touched, neither will I have Houshold-vessels of Earth, for earthen-pots, pans and the like; when they fall and break, sounds as if a stone|wall fell.

div.head: Scene 29.
div.stage: Enter the General, and three or four Commanders.

sp.speaker: GEneral.
sp.p: On my soul Gentlemen, the boy is an honest boy, and no wayes guilty of this you tax him for.

sp.speaker: Commanders.
sp.p: Pardon us, my Lord, for giving your Excellence notice that the States are jealouse of him for a Spie, but we do not any wayes accuse him.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Will the States examine him, say you?

sp.speaker: Commanders.
sp.p: So we hear, my Lord.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, pray leave me for this time, and I will take care the boy shall be forth-coming, whensoever the State shall require him.

sp.speaker: Commanders.
sp.p: Your Lordships humble Servants —

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: A Spie, it cannot be, for he is neither covetous, nor malicious, re|vengefull, nor irreligious, but I will try him.

div.head: Scene 30.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfulls Chamber-maid, and Mrs. Reformer her Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: CHamber-maid.
sp.p: Mrs. Reformer, pray tell me who that handsome Gentleman is, which follows my Lady about?

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: He is one that is Noble, and Rich, and is in love with my Lady.

sp.speaker: Chamber-maid.
sp.p: Truly it is the strangest way of wooing, that ever was, for my Lady goeth blushing out of one room into another, and he follows her at the heels: In my conscience my Lady is ashamed to sit down, or to bid him leave her company, and surely they must needs be both very weary of walking, but sure he will leave her, when it is time to go to bed.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: It is to be hoped he will.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfull, and Sir Serious Dumb following her.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Madam, you will tire your self and the Gentleman, with walking about your house, wherefore pray sit down.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: What! To have him gaze upon my face.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Why, your face is a handsome face, and the owner of it is ho|nest, wherefore you need not be ashamed, but pray rest your self.—

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Pray perswade him to leave me, and then I will.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady intreats you to leave her to her self.

div.stage: Sir Serious Dumb writes then, and gives Reformer his Table-book to read.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: He writes he cannot leave you, for if his body should depart, his soul will remain still with you.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: That will not put me out of countenance, because I shall not be sensible of its presence, wherefore I am content he should leave his soul, so that he will take his body away.

div.stage: He writes, and gives Reformer the Book.

sp.speaker: Reformer reads.
sp.p: He writes, that if you will give him leave once a day to see you, that he will depart, and that he will not disturb your thoughts, he will only wait upon your person for the time he lives, he cannot keep himself long from you.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: But I would be alone.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: But if he will follow you, you must indure that with patience, you cannot avoid.

div.stage: Sir Serious Dumb goeth to the Lady Bashfull, and kisseth her hand, and Ex.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: You see he is so civil, as he is unwilling to displease you.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Rather than I will be troubled thus; I will go to some other parts of the World.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: In my conscience, Madam, he will follow you, wheresoever you go.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: But I will have him shut out of my house.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Then he will lye at your gates, and so all the Town will take no|tice of it.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Why so, they will howsoever, by his often visits.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: But not so publick.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Affectionata. Thou must carry a Letter from me, to my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: You will not marry her, you say.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Then pardon me, my Lord, for though I would assist your honest love by any service I can do, yet I shall never be so base an Instrument, as to produce a crime.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Come, come, thou shalt carry it, and I will give thee 500. pounds for thy service.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Excuse me, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: I will give thee a thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I shall not take it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: I will give thee five thousand, nay ten thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I am not covetous, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: I will make thee Master of my whole Estate, for without the assistance, I cannot injoy my Mistriss, by reason she will trust none with our Loves, but thee.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Could you make me Master of the whole World, it could not tempt me to do an action base, for though I am poor, I am honest, and so honest, as I cannot be corrupted, or bribed there-from.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: You said you loved me?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Heaven knows I do above my life, and would do you any ser|vice that honour did allow of.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: You are more scrupulous than wise.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: There is an old saying, my Lord, that to be wise, is to be honest.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter Sir Peaceable Studious, and meets his Ladies maid.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Where is your Lady?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: In her Chamber, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Pray her to come to me?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

div.stage: Enter another Maid to the first.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: Lord, Lord! What a creature my Master is become; since he fell into his musing again, he looks like a melancholy Ghost, that walks in the shades of Moon-shine, or if there be no Ghost, such as we fancie, just such a one seems her, when a week since, he was as fine a Gentleman as one should see amongst a thousand.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: That was because he kiss'd you, Nan.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: Faith it was but a dull clownish part, to meet a Maid that is not ill-favoured, and not make much of her, who perchance have watch'd to meet him, for which he might have clap'd her on the cheek, or have chuck'd her under the chin, or have kiss'd her, but to do or say nothing, but bid me call my Lady, was such a churlish part? Besides, it seemed neither manly, gallantly, nor civilly.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: But it shewed him temperate and wise, not minding such frivilous and troublesome creatures as women are.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: Prithy, it shews him to be a miserable, proud, dull fool.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: Peace, some body will hear you, and then you will be turn'd away.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: I care not, for it they will not turn me away, I will turn my self away, and seek another service, for I hate to live in the house with a Stoick.

div.head: Scene 33.

sp.speaker: AFfectionata.
sp.p: By your face, Sir, there seems a trouble in your mind, and I am restless until I know your griefs.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: It is a secret I dare not trust the aire with!

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I shall be more secret than the aire, for the aire is apt to di|vulge by retorting Ecohes back, but I shall be as silent as the Grave.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: But you may be tortured to confess the truth.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: But I will not confess the truth, if the confession may any wayes hurt, or disadvantage you; for though I will not belye truth by speaking falsely, yet I will conceal a truth, rather than betray a friend. Especially, my Lord and Master: But howsoever, since your trouble is of such concern, I shall not with to know it, for though I dare trust my self, yet perchance you dare not trust me, but if my honest fidelity can serve you any wayes, you may imploy it, and if it be to keep a secret, all the torment that nature hath made, or art invented, shall never draw it from me.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Then let me tell thee, that to conceal it, would damn thy soul.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Heaven bless me! But sure, my Lord, you cannot be guilty of such sins, that those that doth but barely hear, or know them, shall be damned.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul,
sp.p: But to conceal them, is to be an Actor.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: For Heaven sake then keep them close from me, if either they be base or wicked, for though love prompt me to inquire, hoping to give you ease in bearing part of the burthen, yet Heaven knows, I thought my love so honourable placed on such a worthy person, and guiltless soul, as I might love and serve without a scandal, or a deadly sin.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Come, you shall know it.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I'l rather stop my ears with death.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Go, thou art a false boy.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: How false a boy howsoever you think me, I have an honest soul and heart that is ready to serve you in any honest way, but since I am de|ceived, and couzened into love by false reports, finding the best of man-kind basely wicked, and all the World so bad, that praise nothing good, and strives to poyson vertue, I will inancor my self, and live on Antidotes of prayers, for fear of the infection.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: And I will not you pray for me?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I cannot chose, my Lord, for gratitude inforces me; First, because I have loved you, next, because I have served you; and give me leave to kiss your hand, and then there drop some tears at my departure.

div.stage: Weeping kneels down, and kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Rise, you must not go away until you have cleared your self from being a spie.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I fear no accusations,
